pros: I joined TGH 13 years ago, signing up to volunteer at the hospital. The kindness from the Director of Volunteer Services that encouraged me to apply for a role in People and Talent (HR) made all the difference. Through endless resources and investments in our Team Members, many have stories of continued growth and development as it’s our norm. To this day, TGH has not stopped investing in our people, where we read of other organizations cutting these resources when navigating difficult financial times. I am incredibly proud to be a part of the nearly 11,000 team members truly making a difference in the lives of those that entrust us with their care.
cons: We have grown from a prior community based hospital with now more than 130 locations and a true Health System. As with any growth in any organization, it can come with challenges, however those challenges are easily navigated thanks to the culture of collaboration and teamwork.

job_title: Unit Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros:
The CEO John is fantastic. They try to cultivate a good culture within the organization, however the day to day entirely depends on your direct manager and supervisor. Depending on the unit you work you can have drastically different experiences. 

As a teaching hospital this is a great place to start and you will see the most complex cases. They do provide wage differentials for weekends and night shifts which can increase your pay. 

The benefits are excellent and comprehensive, many older people continue to work here specifically for the benefits. They provide tuition reimbursement and a "clinical ladder" which helps you advance in your position and get wage bonuses. They also reimburse fees for licenses and certifications.
cons:
Low wages compared to the private hospitals in the area. High patient to staff ratios. After the pandemic there is a considerable support staff and nursing shortage. There have been recent wage increases across the board, but pay is still not very competitive. 

A big con is that you have to park offsite for the first 2-3 years of employment and take a shuttle in to campus, this can take anywhere from 10-30 minutes and means you have to arrive extra early for your shift. I've been working there since 2019, it is now early 2022 and I still don't have parking garage privileges. Once you do get garage parking on campus you have to pay $10 per paycheck for parking. Everyone gets to park in the garage for free on weekends and holidays, and you qualify for the garage if you work nightshift regardless of seniority (but still have to pay the fee).

pros: Great medical benefits, good dental benefits. Decent advancement opportunities, free training courses for leadership, project management, etc.
cons:
Rigid, old-school mentality culture: they don't display salary information and when you ask HR for salary information for an internal opening while you are an employee, they say they cannot share that with you and they assure you that you will be compensated fairly based on your experience. The lack of transparency feels a bit disrespectful and like they are shooting themselves in the foot considering the plethora of companies that offer that information up in a job description.

Parental leave: They only offer maternity leave, not paternity leave. It is only 12 weeks and it is unpaid. If you have the accrued time off (420 hours required to be covered for 12 weeks of pay. It takes two years to get to 420 hours of accrued time off, and that is if you don't use any), then you can pay yourself while on leave.

Subcultures do not match hospital culture. The CEO preaches one thing, but departmental subcultures do not line up.

It is difficult to get more than a 3% raise even if you excel at your job. It has to be "justified" and they really only give 4%, rarely over 5% no matter who you are within the organization.

Grind and burnout culture.

review_title: There are perks, but lacks a good work environment
pros:
Great benefits. 
Many opportunities to advance. Want to try a new specialty? Want to go into administration? 
You can relatively easily switch specialties at TGH. 
Wonderful coworkers to work with. Incompetent people are fired.  
Not ALL the doctors are heartless.
We can fill in our own schedule. Also, it is relatively easy to go to school and work here because management will schedule you around days that you are in school. 
This is a great place to "see it all" and obtain valuable experience. That is why I am still here after two years. 
We have an amazing, excellent lift team and security force. 
Neat technology, like our ICU bedside monitors, vein finders, and CorTrak.
cons:
The pay is insulting. My pay has only increased by $2/hour over the past two years despite the fact my responsibilities (charge nurse, preceptor, unit expert) have increased. 

Senior management understaffs us and then wonders why there are problems with patient care (can't go into detail here). They don't listen to the people in the trenches, but they make a show of it by doing rounds on the units and talking to us. 

The work is extremely tough. Tougher than at other hospitals (can't go into detail, once again.)

TGH is very cheap when it comes to purchasing every-day equipment like IV lines. They go for cheap material whenever they can even if it is of inferior quality.

review_title: Strong Leadership and Staff support at TGH!
pros: Supportive Leadership, Encourages professional growth, Truly wants everyone to succeed, Promotes understanding of other departmental functions, and really does everything possible to be transparent with the entire organization. On top of daily rounds on the units from Nurse Managers, Leaders all across the organization round monthly to different units to see where the hospital can improve patient safety and satisfaction. It encourages dialogue and action to make everyone better across the hospital. I love working at TGH because I can honestly say that no two days are the same and no matter what, I feel support from the leadership on a daily basis.
cons: The hospital is incredibly busy and there is always change. I am incredibly proud to say that I work for an organization that does embrace the changes. If someone is okay with change and embraces those factors, TGH is perfect because TGH will change with the healthcare environment surrounding it. I would not consider that necessarily a con; however, the pace of the organization is not for everyone.

pros: I worked at TGH for over 5 years.  The hospital offers excellent benefits.  The ATO/vacation accrual is generous, however, an employee is not always granted a request for time off.  The medical benefits were outstanding in the past but are rapidly changing. The hospital is a great place to learn for those who are willing.  There are many opportunities for growth and learning, if management likes you.
cons: Many decisions to promote employees are based on who likes you and not based on knowledge of the job.  People get promoted based on who they know or who they are related to in the company.  Favoritism is rampant in many of the departments.  Many of the positions require long hours without breaks.  While breaks are required by law, some employees simply cannot leave their work station/nursing unit.  Human Resources is ineffective.  As for culture/values, what you see is not what you get.

review_title: Very pleased with my choice to work as RN in varied ICU's at TGH.
pros: If you work hard and prove yourself you will be developed (specialty training, charge position, etc.) by management.
cons: Pay is lower than most. But I believe the acuity of the patients and resources TGH has make up for it.

review_title: Making the news for advancement but employees are very unhappy and overworked
pros: Lower management and employees care about putting patients first. Very nice people here. Caring and want to do well.
cons: Management is nice but are not usually qualified for the positions they are put in. When we remove people from positions, they are rarely replaced. When someone with 6 years of experience leaves hiring someone with no experience does not fill a the void. Operations does not talk to IT leadership. Patients sadly do not come first when looking at the big picture talking to leadership. If you have Epic experience they do not even consider it as better than having regular IT experience like other areas of the country. Implementing new software and command center with no new employees, overworked is never a good idea for good outcomes.

pros: You can learn a lot as a floor nurse-a lot of cutting edge procedures-very busy-a lot of education
cons:
Many-so top heavy with white coat nurses that dont want to be floor nurses-that sit around in mtgs all day -justifying their jobs by micromanaging floor nurses
Kudos to David Stratz for the only board member voting no on a 30k stipend for them-he has integrity-
A nurse tech may not make 30k-and they spend the most time with patients -save a lot of their lives-work very hard-
A board member wants 30k to meet 6 times a year for mtgs-with catered lunches- those people have never done a hard day of work- and their expertise is to tell the staff to be like resort staff and clinically perfect- very stressful - it takes a special kind of person to take care of sick people in this environment -and it takes a certain kind of person who doesnt care about people to be senior management

review_title: Has Great Strengths & Large Gaps at Same Time
pros: TGH really tries to take care of employees (e.g. birthday breakfast, benefits, etc..).  There is no short cutting care, equipment or supplies for patients.  Healthcare benefits are excellent.  Lots of truly good people to work with.
cons:
Too many priorities and initiatives that make it hard to know what to focus on.   More tasks keep being added without anything being removed, which contributes to staff leaving.   
Many in senior leadership don't truly listen to employee concerns or communicate well with employees.  
Lack of respect for job knowledge if you're not a nurse.

review_title: Hospital Great Individual Dpeartments are poor
pros: The hospital truly cares for its employees. They do many things to support a positive environment within the hospital. Tries hard to make it a great place to work. C suite managment is outstanding
cons: Individual departments however are terrible. They are often run by managers that have no clue how to manage or do the job of the personell they are managing. They spend large amounts of time in meetings which makes it difficult to allow them to manage. Senior level managment doe snothing to support their employees at all which is rather disappointing. The pay is way on the low end and they constantly use the benefits as a crutch but the benefits are only a fraction better than other hospitals.

review_title: If you like working 8-12 hours straight with NO BREAKS, except a 30 min lunch IF you're lucky...
pros:
Management does care about hard working staff.
In general, the atmosphere is one of caring-for the patients anyway.
The cafeteria is pretty nice
It's nice to have a Starbucks onsite
cons:
No breaks
Old, broken beds and equipment
Having to take a SHUTTLE from a pretty far away lot to the hospital is very frustrating.  They have no system for timing and you must arrive at least 25 mins before your scheduled work time to be on time.  The shuttle drivers can be rude and disrespectful if you voice your opinion when that waiver from the APPOINTED 3 stop route because ONE employee wants to be dropped off first!

review_title: Best Way To Gain Experience In Nursing In The Tampa Bay Area
pros: Great health benefits. Fantastic experience. Looks good on a resume.
cons: Middle management that is filled with "yes men" and numbers and stats guys.  On the flip side, there are some managers that just holding out for retirement, by hiding in their office and dipping for yet another pointless meeting. I swear one of my managers could have died while sitting in her office at her desk and the staff would not have noticed for days...Only being concerned when she didn't leave for meetings. Lots of politics and favoritism.  Nurse to patient ratios are worsening. Lots of talk about making money but still only are getting the standard 3% raise.

review_title: Needs  mid and upper level management improvment
pros: Most co workers are great, supplies available for patients most of the time, night shift charge nurses on my unit were mostly all awesome to work with
cons: Responsibilities continue to increase on nurses yet management does not look at support staff to assist nurses, certain units the management crosses the professional /personal line by hanging out with preferred members of the unit and playing favorites, cliniicans play favorites as well vs being professional and courteous to all the staff, policies not uniformlly applied, crazy busy all the time.

review_title: good if your a doctor or nurse. Sucks otherwise.
pros: benefits, sometimes they give you meal tickets to the cafeteria.
cons: nurses and doctors abuse patient transporters and will treat you like a second class citizen, TGH loves there doctors and nurses and will say it 100 times over, but supporting departments (environmental services, patient transport, dietary) gets no love and gets verbal abuse from nurses and they treat you like your expendable and worthless. the pay is garbage for supporting departments (but better believe they take care of their nurses and doctors!) if you're not coming in here with a degree, don't come at all. The things they will do to you will not be worth the low pay they give.

pros: Decent ATO accrual and insurance, great experience, community reputation is fabulous and nurses are well respected. Many opportunities to learn, tuition reimbursement.
cons: WAY too much management in nursing department which results in micromanagement, pay is actually insulting. By far the lowest paying hospital in the area with the highest demands in patient care and acuity. Ridiculous amount of repetitive training monthly that is mandatory. Incredibly stressful environment, working with residents and private physicians can be overwhelming at times. High turnover rate

review_title: Take the bad with the good
job_title: Sterile Processing Specialist II in Tampa, FL
pros: Fast-Paced, never a boring day doing the same old thing
cons: Where do I start? Management focuses too heavily on productivity and how much you can get done versus quality (all while expecting nothing less than perfection), pay is notoriously the lowest in the area, even with industry certification (which is now mandatory to even get an interview), and that's if you can even pass the personality test which allows your application to land in HR's hands.

pros: This is a great hospital to learn at as a new RN, Many experiences and opportunities to grow as a nurse. The insurance is great, very affordable,
cons: This is a very lager hospital and difficult to navigate around. Health care insurance offered requires you to use only TGH or USF affiliated groups. After giving my two week notice my manager did not speak to me once. She literally stood across from me and spoke to another nurse and did not acknowledge me leaving after 2 years of service

review_title: Great experience and highest level of acuity I have ever taken care of at any hospital.
pros: Great experience and learning things you don't see anywhere else. This is a great hospital to start your career in! If you have been a nurse for a while and are getting tired it may be a bit too busy. The people I work with are great and very knowledgable. We usually get patients that other hospitals have messed up on and we fix them. It really is a great place to work. Just wish they paid more.
cons: Harder work then most other hospitals. The average acuity is much higher then other area hospitals. We get the sickest of the sick here. So with that being said you are definitely going to work harder for your money.

review_title: Some great worker bees with horrible management.
pros: The hospital is an exciting place to be akin to a small city.  Many "lines of business" and plenty of occupations to work in.  Some very nice, caring people.
cons: In IT, the name of the game is "play the party line."  It's not about merit, skills, or knowledge, but sucking up and riding the gravy train that is the hospital doing well financially.  They would never make in the non-profit world where ROI matters.  IT management here is not about talent but seniority and favoritism.

pros: i worked for TGH as an inpatient rehab aide and came back as a student physical therapy intern. This was before I went to school to earn my DPT. The therapists and my manager were amazing, they were eager to teach me and truly cared about their patients.
cons: As with most healthcare jobs there was a requirement to work one holiday and one weekend a month. It took time to gain the trust and respect of the nursing staff. I am unsure if this is due to my job title, or lack of experience, but after about four months I felt as if I was on the same team as the nursing staff!

pros: I have never worked with a better bunch of people in my entire career.  The character and dedication of these folks is beyond measure.  We are family.  The benefits and vacation are excellent.
cons: TGH senior management demonstrates a contempt and distrust of its employees that passes understanding.  It seems as if they endeavor to crush the spirit of the very good people that work there.  Top value is placed on compliance rather than imagination, dedication or drive.  Many good and effective people, management and staff, have been fired or forced out for trying to make a difference.

job_title: Registered Nurse Medical Surgical in Tampa, FL

1. Opportunities to switch specialties
2. Opportunities to do research

6. Opportunities for OT, if you want it. No mandatory OT.
cons:

4. Chronically understaffed
5. As a new nurse, you have very little choice about where they put you when you are hired.

review_title: Great learning experience, very low pay.
pros: The critical care rotation program is a great learning experience.  It is the fastest way to gain experience right out of school as possible.  There is a positive work culture and amazing coworkers who take an interest in developing new employees.
cons: Expect to be mentally and physically exhausted for at least the first year.  Often the hospital is short staffed, expect to be asked to work 16 to 24 hour shifts.  Many nurses are required to work nights which takes a toll on their physical and mental health.  Education can often be excessive with multiple mind labs due every month.

pros: Excellent place for learning. Varied patient base provides cases ranging from very basic to highly unusual. Opportunity to work with experts who are willing to share knowledge. Administration demonstrated an aggressive plan for employee growth and development and a vision for internal and external expansion. Can be exciting for highly motivated people.
cons: Staffing and equipment needs can lower potentials and cause frustration.  There seemed to be efforts for improvement on the horizon.  Some area managers not as supportive as they could be.

review_title: Great company but IT leadership is behind the times
pros: Competitive salary for the area, good benefits overall. PTO really starts to accrue the longer you are there. Many people with 400+ hours of PTO.  IT is located off campus but close to downtown Tampa and the hospital.
cons: IT leadership is gun shy to innovate on their own because there are a lot of unplanned outages and people are afraid of getting fired by the next screw up. Lots of turnover of staff.

pros: Some of the best employees I've ever worked with.  USF affiliation. Wonderful marketing, branding and community opinion. New CEO giving hope for change.
cons: Absentee management.  Entrenched corporate culture that believes the TGH way is the only way.  Aging infrastructure.  Eliminated traditional pension.  Decreasing benefits.  Cutting employee hours while touting the amount of cash we have on hand.  Large debt with decreasing revenue.  Implementing projects without ROI concerns.  Lack of opportunities for advancement.   Over spent on EMR that still doesn't perform as we would like.

job_title: Business Operations Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: All of the positives associated with working for a large company (benefits, training, etc), while also maintaining the feel of a smaller company. The people you work with truly care about you as a person and want you to grow.
cons: There were some poor managers in place that significantly affected morale in a negative way. That has since been corrected.

pros: Excellent benefits- very good copayment-based health insurance, 8+ hours of ATO per pay period (depends on years of service), competitive 403B with matching up to 5% of salary. Competitive tuition reimbursement benefit (4k/year). Relatively easy to transfer between departments at 6+ months. Lots of opportunities for CEs, certifications, and higher education.
cons: Very busy, very frequently understaffed. Currently having some financial difficulty/budget shortfalls, on a hiring freeze for external applicants as of february 2016. Workload in surgical services departments is frequently unpredictable and there is a high turnover rate. Compensation for inexperienced RNs (<5 yrs) is not competitive compared to other hospitals in the area.

pros: Great experience with a variety of patient conditions, a Starbucks and McDonalds, the cafeteria, sick child care, the benefits, opportunity to work at other locations in the clinics.
cons: Nurses work frequently short, bordering on unsafe. The company views nurses as expendable. There is a culture of "writing up" nurses, even among co-workers. Many nurses have been fired recently, especially with the hospitals financial difficulties. The parking situation is such that new employees have to park off-site and have to take unreliable shuttles to get back and forth from the main campus. The culture is such that doctors speaking disrespectfully to the nurses is considered acceptable.

pros: Excellent facility with quality care providers. Information Technology department one of the best run I've had the pleasure of working with. All in all the implementation went well. McDonald's and Starbucks on-site.
cons: Having to park at remote location and shuttled in to work. Realize the parking garage is for visitors but wouldn't worry as much if allowed to park onsite.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Tampa, FL
pros: Excellent team work at TGH. People have a pleasant attitude for the most part and enjoy working there. There are a couple of notorious units but overall, it's a good healthcare facility to work for.
cons: The pay is not competitive. Even with the raise they gave me to make them more competitive, it still was not competitive. The parking situation at TGH is a total nightmare. Be prepared to waste part of your day shuttling around.

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros:
Truly able to work and do what is best for the patient 
Management if very supportive and will work with you to solve the barrier to success
Recognition for a job well done.

Prepayment for college to pursue  advancement.

management is very transparent and informative on expectations and future plans
cons: Growing pains:  Revolving door of staff results in frequent coverage issues.  Often have to cover another unit in addition to your own ...eventually leads to burn out and frequent call ins.

pros: Great employees who want to work, learn, and advance but management is the problem.
cons: Management staff does not have the qualifications to manage and everyone ever dealt with, micromanaged. Poor at leadership, mentor ship and advancing their employees.

review_title: Very stressfull and demanding company to work for.
pros: A teaching company allied with a large number of other institutions.many specialties are offer.Very large population.
cons: company is extremely busy and understaff in many departments.crosstraining employees does not fix the problems.employees still work same hours with less employees.due to very radical termination actions...

pros: Good benefits and access to excellent healthcare within all specialties are offered to employees. TGH is a Level 1 Trauma Center / Teaching Facility partnering with the University of South Florida and as Medical Staff, you are exposed to a vast amount of learning opportunities on a daily basis.
cons: From the medical staff side of this facility, Mid-Level Management to Department Managers are often promoted to these positions because of who they know and not what they know or their ability to lead by example... They do NOT practice what they preach, are extremely quick to criticize and rush to judgement without hearing all of those involved in the most minor issues. I, personally, was only involved in one issue over my many years of employment at TGH but, was witness to many, many of these types of minor issues and the majority of them were handled with poor managerial judgement leading to unjust disciplinary action on exemplary employees but, if you socialize with some of the managers outside of the work environment, lets just say that, unfortunately,, a blind eye will be turned.

pros: Builds character, thickens your skin, and I guarantee you will never take a decent position at a decent organization for granted again after spending a few years in a position here.
cons: Worst management, worst pay, worst work conditions, ridiculously corrupt HR department, and THE worst patients in all of Tampa by far. This place will drive even the best, most hardworking, mentally stable employee to the brink of insanity. You can find employees there having breakdowns, crying, threatening to walk off daily.

review_title: Change of CEO was the dimise of TGH
pros: It was great when the Old CEO Ron H was there! He was truly Hands ON with all the TGH employees & Genuinely Cared.
cons: I left after working there 7+ years after James Burkhart became CEO He has no business being in Health-CARE because he truly does not care about anything but the $, & the employees, the organization, & most importantly the patients suffer

review_title: Great company and even better people
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Tampa, FL
pros: The people who work here are of the highest quality across the board. I am surrounded by some of the best and brightest people in Tampa everyday. The benefits are unmatched. Paid time off is off of the charts, and you can cash out the hours that are not used. Work/life balance is top notch. The work is meaningful. The company has a major footprint in the area.
cons: Turnover, which is to be expected at any large company.

review_title: Tampa General Hospital was a great place to work. The people there where very nice and knowelegable
pros: The Doctors, Nurses and other employees where, very  smart, kind, and friendly.   I truly would love to go back to work at Tampa General Hospital.
cons: The only bad thing I would say is to pay the employees better and have a scholarship plan, so if the employees want to go back to school.

job_title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographer in Tampa, FL
pros: Great learning opportunity due to size
cons: This place throws money at stupid things to appear like they care for employees, and many of them fall for it. But when it really comes down to it, they do not care at all about the individual employee. If you are half broken and on fire, as long as you can make them money, you will. Everything from the top is so ingenuine and infuriating. They are all about image and money. In the department, there is zero consistency except that the only people who matter are the ones who have been there forever. Upward movement is only possible for those who have worked there for 20 years.

review_title: Great place to learn don't stay.
